caseTitle: ISAAC STEPHEN NETTEY MARBELL v RICHARD AKWEI & ors
summary: This 1952 West African Court of Appeal decision in the Gold Coast (now Ghana) involved two consolidated land disputes concerning adjoining plots on Farrar Avenue, Accra. In the second case, Richard Akwei, who had conveyed land to Faris, was estopped from claiming title against Emelia Cofie after having supported Faris' defense in a prior suit where Cofie successfully established superior title. Though not a formal party in that earlier case, Akwei was found to be vitally interested in its outcome, as the validity of his own conveyance was at stake. The court held that by standing by and allowing Faris to litigate on his behalf, Akwei was bound by the judgment. The principle of estoppel by privity of interest was affirmed, citing English and regional precedents. In the first case, Isaac Marbell successfully appealed a lower court ruling, with the appellate court correcting an evidentiary error regarding the proper interpretation of conveyance deeds linked to Vidal James Buckleâ€™s acquisitions.
verdict: Appeal allowed in Marbell v. Akwei; appeal dismissed in Akwei v. Cofie on grounds of estoppel.
winningSide: Isaac Stephen Nettey Marbell (in first action); Emelia Chicher Cofie (in second action)

jurisdiction.court: West African Court of Appeal, Gold Coast

citations: Yode Kwao v. Kwasi Coker, 1 W.A.C.A. 168
Mercantile Investment and General Trust Co. v. River Plate Trust Loan and Agency Co. (1894), 1 Ch. D. 595
rationaleHighlights: A person not formally a party may be estopped if vitally interested and in privity of interest with a party.
Standing by while another defends one's legal interest binds the non-party to the outcome.
Estoppel applies where a prior conveyance's validity is challenged in earlier litigation.
Trial judge correctly applied precedent from Yode Kwao v. Kwasi Coker.
Vendor cannot re-litigate title once it has been judicially rejected in a prior case involving the vendee.
